pros: As far as my experience tells me, Church World Service is an employer that cares about its employees' well-being. The job requirements are demanding because of the contract it has to fulfill with the Office of Refugee Resettlement but it has done its best to negotiate the terms to make it manageable for employees. While the energy commitment can be considerable, management does what it can to promote a healthy work-life balance for employees and make sure employees get compensated fairly especially for any extra hours they need to work.
cons: The travel commitments for Level 2 and 3 caseworkers can be very demanding, and the amount of cases and quick turn-around times can be demanding for level 1.

pros: Stable job, good work/life balance, great medical
cons: Hard to move up the hierarchy, you need to be liked by management

pros: Create Place to work. 7.5 work hrs per day. Strict with SOP.
cons: None so far. Been a great ride

pros: Medical aid benefit (Discovery Priority Classic) Deployment cash per trip out of South Africa
cons: Being away from home as this job requires a lot of travel around Sub-Saharan Africa

pros: Great work culture and welcoming staff; good benefits.

pros: Especially in the Immigration and Refugee Program, the people are kind, collaborative, and passionate.

review_title: Great place to work and make difference in this world.

cons: Stressful work as every disaster and war means more work.

pros: The work environment is quit flexible when it comes to work location (full remote) and time.

pros: Travel through out Africa to process Refugee cases for resettlement.

pros: CWS has an incredible team of people from the local office up through HQ. Staff at every level are valued and supported. The organization has strong progressive values and takes a proactive stance on issues affecting refugees, immigrants, racial equity and inclusiveness. Although it is a faith based organization, it is very diverse and inclusive of people of any belief system.
cons: The work can be impacted by the current political environment towards refugees & immigrants.

pros: Fulfilling to work with refugees.
cons: Senior management in Nairobi is hell-bent on playing unfair politics.

review_title: Great place to work!  Supportive supervisor and friendly co-workers
pros: Great benefits! Manager did not micro-manage me.
cons: Small non-profit so may be limited in career opportunities.

pros: Salary is manageable for everyone
cons: Need to increase their salary.

review_title: Can't get out of their own way...
pros: The organization has a great philosophy on how to meet the needs of the world's poorest people. The organization is very progressive and serves as a strong voice for progressive Christian denominations. It's work on the ground is phenomenal. Unfortunately, the management of the organization overshadows its true potential as a great organization.
cons: Through several rough years and staff cuts, the leadership of both the CEO and CFO has remained the same. At no point did anyone think that perhaps top leadership was to blame for the shortcomings of the organization and their fiscal issues. Instead, they cut staff, placed more work on the shoulders of the existing staff and expected to right the ship. This philosophy thus far as proven to be wrong. The CEO and CFO continue to be employed and the ship is still sinking. They refuse to hear and implement the ideas of front line fundraising staff, make decisions without the input of those who they effect and play favorites with a select few. They do not pay employees anywhere near competitive salaries in any of the markets where they have offices, yet expect 3 times the amount of work. They continue to put all of their hopes in a failing fundraising system and stamp out any innovation. Yet, those at the top of the organization stay comfortable while the consequences of years of bad decision making are felt by those on the front lines.

review_title: Its a really great organization and the work that they do is important.
pros: The team and managers are very professional and the environment is quite pleasant, overall.
cons: There can be micromanagement from mid-level managers to the rest of the team.

review_title: Its a highly professional work place
pros: Policies are followed to the latter. Zero tolerance to sexual harassment and fraud.
cons: Pay can still be better.

pros: Defined structures, that work most time
cons: Many rules and regulations that are considered.

pros: Flexi hours from 8 to 5
cons: Low salary need for improvement

pros: A lot of good things
cons: Not much to complain about

job_title: Associate Director of Resource Mobilization in Washington, DC
pros: Solid mission, generally nice and capable staff, strong advocacy unit.
cons: Programs not particularly innovative. Mediocre salaries. Odd structure.

job_title: Lead Teacher in Murrells Inlet, SC
pros: working with kids is fun
cons: working with adults sucks a lot

pros: Staff development , Staff care, Trainings, Good renumeration, Professional
cons: Pressure, Field work, Stressful, Tiresome

review_title: Great company if you're willing to have a huge impact on refugees or immigrants lives
pros: You have a work-life balance
cons: When refugees are banned from entering the country, it means there is no work

pros: becouse i feel that confortable and its my hobby
cons: there is no downside for me

pros: Great place to serve the less fortunate.
cons: They speak inclusivity and social justice but show bias and discriminatory practices against national staff

job_title: Employment Case Manager in Durham, NC
pros: CWS has a noble cause in helping refugees become established and self-sufficient in the Triangle. The ESL teachers, case managers, volunteer coordinator and employment specialists are wonderful, caring, dedicated professionals.
cons: Unfortunately, the management and program directors are more interested in numbers than the well-being of their clients and employees. The director's style of training and communication is to manipulate, belittle, harshly correct in front of other co-workers and obsessively micro-manage, making sure that everyone does every little thing to her liking. The work environment became so toxic that I was literally unable to focus on my work or perform my job to the best of my ability. Never been so mistreated in my life. It's sad that an organization with such a good cause is run by someone that cannot even show decent respect or kindness to the employees that administer the programs, working long hours for very little pay. Also, CWS does not have any human resource professional available for you to turn to if you need someone to talk to about being continually mistreated by your supervisor. If you end up working here and have a problem, don't bother trying to talk to the director, they will simply try to make your job even more miserable to the point that you will want to resign....Of course, this is much more convenient than having to find new management! My advice, stay away until there is new management.

job_title: Dari Interpreter in New York, NY
pros: It's good, honest work, and one definitely feels a sense of fulfillment while working here. The staff is dedicated to the humanitarian cause, and the clients are usually quite appreciative.
cons: Because of how understaffed the company is, the caseworkers really push as hard as they can to get people to help out. This isn't a job for those who can easily be pushed around. I was just an interpreter, but after about two sessions, I was asked to do more things, essentially becoming an unofficial caseworker quite quickly, using my own car and gas to pick up clients, take them to appointments where caseworkers didn't show up, wrote up reports and summaries for what I did and sent it back to the office. I felt bad for the staff and attempted to help, but I ended up abused.

review_title: Good intentions good cause totally mismanaged non-profit
pros: Many of the staff are very dedicated, hard working and really beilieve in the mission of the organization.
cons: Terrible management, the HR department is a joke, abusive behavior by some of the executive leaders, program directors and senior staff is not only tolerated but excused, very high turnover of qualified staff. Also financially the organization is not doing well and donations are way down.

job_title: Program Specialist in New York, NY
pros: great colleagues, everyone supports everyone, very team-oriented environment, middle management cares about those beneath it, union environment (both plus and minuses), company does good work and cares about its mission.
cons: upper management is not in tune with what's happening elsewhere, lack a streamlined strategy and goals for the entire organization. Organization does resettlement and disaster relief yet does not do a good job utilizing staff across its agencies and streamline its work. I was there for four years, and still don't know everything the organization does as a lot of it is siloed. Administrative work is out of Indiania, headquarters is in NY and then there are offices and individuals working everywhere. Furthermore, if management likes you, they will jump through hoops to get you want you need and often treatment is not universal.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Good benefits, flexible work environment and most of the program directors and employees in both the national and global offices are very dedicated, collaborative and helpful.
cons: Low pay even for an NGO, the organization is undergoing many changes in an effort to move forward but there are too many longtime employees who are unwilling or unable to accept this and need to retire or leave, the union in the NY office is out of control and continually makes unrealistic demands, communication between senior management and staff needs improvement

pros: The org. still has good intentions and although most talented staff are gone or have been laid off, there are still some dedicated staff left in the field offices.
cons: Pay is abominal, layoffs last year were handled disastrously by HR and there is serious misuse of government. and org. money by CEO, CFO and senior management as well as some of the global offices where corruption is rife. I cannot believe CWS has not been investigated by the state dept. or shut down yet. Hopefully its just a matter of time......

pros:
I worked with some of the most compassionate and well educated people on the planet! 

I enjoyed the work I was doing and the people we were doing for.
cons:
A divisive Manager with no Emotional Intelligence  went unchecked for a very long time. When the long standing issue was finally addressed it was far too late!

Being micromanaged by people I reported to indirectly.

pros: Diverse staff who have diverse professional achievements, yearly conferences, you will assist vulnerable individuals, working with likeminded people is a plus. They have offices internationally, but upward mobility is not common. Work is not routine and you will be challenged and will grow as a person from the experience in assisting others, but pay is less than other resettlement agencies.
cons: Management at the highest levels in Headquarters is the reason for high turnover, poor management, negative atmosphere in NY Headquarters, low morale and discontent is evident within an unhappy staff, staff are over worked - and under appreciated. High number of people being laid off and resigning due to poor leadership and poor financial mismanagement. Expect to take a step back in your career.

review_title: A place for growth and impact
job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: CWS is a mission driven employer in the field of refugee services and development--It's feel good work in a professional setting. I worked for CWS more than two years and gained significant skills in the areas of professionalism, grant writing, management, and  program development. There are excellent mentors on the floor.
cons: There are some significant communication gaps between folks at the top and the rest of the global and national networks.

pros: The environment was a very happy and encouraging one. I never left there feeling like I didn't accomplish my goal of helping someone that day. The people in the office were very sweet and helpful.
cons: Sometimes it was hard to find enough volunteers to help out during classes or in the event of transporting refugees.

pros:
Very interesting colleagues - early career Americans, some who were passionate about resettlement and protection issues and very talented and motivated colleagues from Kenya

Travel opportunities, several weeks in each refugee camp setting for processing

Opportunity to get to know local translators

Intense experience hearing inspiring stories of courage and sacrifice from refugees
cons:
Emotionally challenging work

Lack of consistent schedule with travel

Frequent change and updates for organization, procedures and local management could be distracting and discouraging at times

pros: Great environment - everyone is more than willing to help each other out if needed to make sure our clients get the best help
cons: A lot of wasted time - socializing is nice in a professional environment, but not at the expense of not getting your work done

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Very little positive at this point. CWS was once a good place to work. But the organization is barely holding on, and massive layoffs in 2015 were handled poorly. Organization has a self-image of being a nice employer, but that is not true.
cons: Unfortunately, those in upper management now are in over their heads, and with a weak board of directors, there is very little oversight. The CEO and CFO need to be replaced with new leadership.

pros: Working at CWS gives one the opportunity  to work with a diverse population of clients. Interns are very independent and are exposed to a variety of immigration law issues and projects: Naturalization, DACA, VAWA,  U-Visa, AOS...
cons: The internship is likely unpaid so the student may need to apply for a grant or stipend through their school.

review_title: Executives didn't manage change towards decentralization well.
pros: Good people working on good programs.
cons: I worked at CWS during a period of decentralization and I found that the executive management had lost too much control and oversight of branch offices. Perhaps it is better now but if you are considering working there, it is worth checking into this.

pros: Being able to  be part of a company that helps others is amazing.
cons: There is not always a lot of support for employees as even the supervisors are a bit overworked.  Also, since it's a nonprofit, the pay is not top-notch.

review_title: It’s interesting, it’s my first international organization to work for and the experience has been great so far.
pros: There is travel. Staff care is amazing. Have comprehensive health and life insurance. Young workforce. Dynamic.
cons: Dependent of the US budget, so when policy or presidents changes, the program is affected.

pros: It is very rewarding to work with refugees and immigrants. Friendly environment and support from all staff, it is one big team all working together to give the best service
cons: Not the best salary, this job does not pay too much. There is not a lot of budget to provide staff the latest technology

pros: The work that CWS does is a noble cause. I feel like CWS makes a real difference with refugees in ways other companies cannot.
cons:
If you can work under management that constantly belittles you, degrades you as a person, does not care for you personally, have the ability internalize harsh criticism.... then CWS is for you. 
If you value working conditions that are fair, respectable, honest, and encouraging.... then CWS is NOT for you.

pros: Highly motivational and intelligent group of people that put all of their efforts to the cause and mission
cons: Not necessarily a con, but due to the nature of their work, the lack of funding really took a toll on the staff

review_title: Good on paper, different in reality

cons: Unnecessarily hierarchical; under-resourced; disorganized.. managers are distant.

pros: Meeting refugees in sub-Saharan Africa and feeling like my work had purpose.
cons: Management rarely supported employees and did not exploit people's skills, rather, management gave employees meaningless tasks in order to keep them busy.

pros: The international employee benefits are reasonable. National (Kenyan) employment salaries need improvement.
cons: The senior leadership responsible for implementing refugee resettlement is incompetent. The managers rule with an iron fist and the workplace culture and morale are very low. While the idea of helping refugees is a noble cause, this organization requires systemic help and new management direction.
